If by communication you mean verbal communication, I am comfortable both with talking and writing. But I prefer talking. For some reason, I tend to impress people and engage their attention far more when I talk my ideas and opinions, rather than say, typing an application, affidavit, blog post or an email - even when I try to say the same thing in both mediums.  Even since I got into law, I found the writing forms a bulk of the communication in bureaucracies AND most of your 'practice' as a junior lawyer - hence I realised I'd have to develop my writing skills or perish. However, despite my fairly good typing skills - writing out things feels dry, contrite and impersonal - I don't get the 'feel' of communicating something when I can't see or hear the other person AND hence, don't get the 'drive' to be as alive, as witty and passionate when I 'talk' using typed/written words.  I can't represent things by gestures, facial expressions and tones when typing. I can't do dramatic pauses or alter the flow of speech for 'effect'. When I try to pull a sarcastic undertone, it goes missed online. Typing emoticons to compensate feels really weird, even if I manage to find the 'correct' one to express how I feel when I say something. The slowness of typed communication as opposed to the fluidity of speech gets my thoughts all muddled and clunky. Hence, I'd devolve to very clinical, dry and logical drivel - the way I'd write an LLM exam paper. Hence, my foray into online discussion forums like Quora and my blog - I have to learn how to express myself better in written communication.

Depends on the objective For structured arguments with factual citations on complex and sensitive issues, written word is my preference. When speaking about a topic, I’m liable to go off on tangents, repeat myself, use excessive hyperbole to make a point when it’s not necessary, phrase something incorrectly and sound like an asshole, stutter, repeat myself, and forget the specific references that I can use to back up my argument (“I remember reading once somewhere that this is a thing because numbers that are there.”) When writing, I can reread my statement multiple times before sending it out to ensure that it conveys exactly what I want it to, and I have the time to look up the exact numbers or the quote I’m referencing, plus fact/context check the other person’s argument. I can also employ eloquent literary techniques in the execution of my explanation for flashy effect that the spoken word prohibits the practice of without prior planning. For interpersonal and social communication, however, I prefer talking face to face. What I gain in structure and planning in the written word, I lose in intonation, emphasis, and over the top hand gesturing. As is well known in the internet community, sarcasm doesn’t translate into text very well. I also find that stuttering, fumbling, and repetition, while detrimental to a measured debate and removed when writing, add something to social interactions when face to face. It’s also far easier to have engaging conversations because the other party can interject, question, and react to what you say as it’s happening. For example, if you’re telling a story of questionable appropriateness for the audience and/or situation, you can cut it off when the other person seems uneasy, instead of just emailing them a raunchy essay. Plus, when communicating by text, the other party doesn’t get to hear my charming voice.

My speech cannot match with my speed of thinking, which is also why I sometimes clutter while speaking, or speak too fast to catch up with the speed of my thoughts. Well, It's kind of under control right now, but still.And yes, direct interaction tires people out and I am able to convey my thoughts better by writing because it gives me the option to think a lot while 'saying' things, which I usually like to do. I usually contradict myself many a times while saying something. I would be saying something and some other part of my brain would be wondering if what I said is actually true. It's like...philosophizing every moment about everything I say, which is why I always prefer to write about what I have to say. Also because it provides a log, so you can read whatever the person said as many times as you wish to.And also, as Leonard Kim pointed out, nobody knows if you haven't showered the whole week or if you're in your boxers, so! Forgive so many also's, and that's why's, eeeep!

The Code speaks to me. Within this side-by-side, Matrix like universe, I’m able to decipher slight disturbances, dual meanings, hidding bugs, possible pathways of actions. When she says, “I’m sleepy.” The Code informs me that she actually means “she’s hungry.” When she says, she “I’m not mad, I just think it’s funny.”, The Code automatically sirens Opposite Speak, and advises a defensive position. When she asks how many women I’ve slept with, The Code, quickly runs an algorithm, finding, through a complex set of equations, the minimum believable number to deliver as feedback. When I speak and her lips tighten, The Code informs me of a Wordlogger attack in progress, warns me to monitor all word choice and tone of voice. When she asks if I like her mother, The Code, in .1 seconds, runs 10000 simulations of A:B testing on possible, low damage answers. When I ask her what she is in the mood to eat and she says, “I don’t know.”, The Code immediately detects “Mexican” food. Mexican. The one true answer. The answer that, if I actually knew her, I would have known all along. I know The Code as The Code. It is all I have known. But you may know it as Mindreading, the ultimate form of girlfriend communication.

The written word. Hands down. When speaking, I stammer. The words I seek elude me, skittering away around the corner on mischievous, silent little paws. Other words - the wrong ones - leap into their places unbidden and unwelcome. They tumble out of my mouth because something has to come out; people are waiting. “I will have that project completed by Thursday,” I tell my boss. “Just waiting to receive the…the…the…masturbation results.” Very weird look from boss. My career is over. I will go crawl into a desk drawer now. An hour later - Crap, I meant maturation results. Yeah, that was it. The phone is even worse than talking to someone in person. There are no facial expressions or body language to interpret, so it’s like I’m only getting a quarter of the communication that’s going on. Torture. When I can write out my thoughts, I have time to chase down those elusive, tricksy little words until I triumphantly capture them and line them up neatly on the screen or page. No squirming, now. Stand up straight. Hey, you - get back here! Before hitting ‘Send’ I can reread, proofread, edit, rephrase, delete, expound, tweak, and obsess. And that’s just for a casual email to a friend. Language is so nuanced, so complex - I don’t understand how anyone can sort through the millions of words that bounce around, plucking exactly the right ones from the ether and stringing them together in coherent sentences at will. It’s like a superpower. One I don’t have. So I will keep poking away at my keyboard and scrawling with my cheap ink pens, because that is how the words and I find each other.

….limit your fidget (If you want to sound credible)- If you want to sound credible, no matter how hard your nose itches, ear tingle or your foot prickle. Do not fidget, twitch, wiggle squirm or scratch. Hand motion near your face and all fidgeting can give your listener the gut feeling you’re fibbing(lying). Magical Smile - If you want someone to feel you are treating them special. Then, never flash a immediate smile. Pause for a moment, soak in their persona. Then let a big warm, responsive smile flood over your face. It will engulf recipient like a warm wave. So the ultimate fantasy will draw their attraction and wanna talk to you. Hello Old Friend- ( Want to converse with a stranger)- When meeting someone, imagine He or She is your old friend. How sad, Life tore you two asunder and now both you reunited at this occasion . The joyful experience start a remarkable chain in your brain and it will ease out the tension in your head and now you want to converse. Small Talk (What to say after “Hi”) - Communication fear is not treatable with any drugs. So, When meeting new people, we always wonder what to say after “Hi” and it restrain us from talking. Big corporate giant and world renowned leader always learn small talk to match the mood. So, learn some small talk, Anecdote, Learn from their body language. So, you have enough information in your head, before you approach them. First Word- Worried about your first word. Fear not, because 80 percent of your listener’s impression has nothing to do with your first word anyway. So, speak out whatever scramble in your head to start with. Parroting (What’s next)- Now, you have started a conversation and don’t know much about him/her. Fear not, before this technique of parroting is much effective in these case. Parroting is the technique of repeating the last words. for example- He- I bought a new car yesterday. you- a car…? He- Yes a black colored, 2000 cc engine, mercedes sedan. When you just repeat last word what he uttered. He feels that you are taking more interest in conversation and excite him to tell more about the stuff like that. This technique is most useful if you want to get some valuable information from somebody. The Nutshell Resume- If you are a job seeker. So always prepare a nutshell resume and remember it in your mind. So, next time you go out and meeting with some business tycoon or corporate big cat. When asked for introduction, don’t give naked interview. Think like What you have which will benefit him and will offer you a job.

1. Travelling in public transport and roaming about alone trying to reach destinations has taught me that a SMILE can do more wonders than anything. When you need a favour from a stranger or ease out a tense situation like interviews, a smile always works. (Worked for me)Some will keep a straight face while some will return a curious, questioning look but that shouldn't discourage you from smiling. But make sure it isn't a plastic smile or a wide grin from ear-to-ear. Keep it genuine and simple. Even when somebody is disagreeing with you, smiling at them makes them more obliged to listen to you. 2. Whenever you are asked a question in an interview or presentation, don't answer immediately just to look like you know everything. You may end up fumbling and stuttering. Take a pause, nod and buy yourself that time to process your thoughts to present it in a more coherent manner.Anyway because you're nervous, you assume the silence to be longer than it really is. 3. Never fold your arms when you are listening or speaking to an authority, a superior or are in formal situations. It is a sign of blocking behaviour and you may come across as under-confident, nervous or defensive. 4. While interacting with your friends and informal acquaintances, addressing them with their name and a light touch on their arm will make you more likeable to them. But know when to do it so as to not come across as a creep :D 5. (And my favourite) A lot of people can't differentiate between knowledge or brilliance and confidence. So, if you act like you know what you're doing, others will tend to believe that too and rally around.

I prefer written, because it gives me time to formulate my thoughts. I can go back and re-read both what I wrote and the response(s). It minimizes (though it doesn't eliminate) my obsessing over every nuance. I spend less time wondering if I'm mis-remembering the look on her face or the hesitation just before he answered. I can read precisely what was written and be content. The main exception to this is my inner circle, which I prefer to spend time with in-person, though this becomes a catch-22. I'm more comfortable with written communication because it gives me time to process whatever I want to say. My words can come out as I intend, rather than pouring out of me in an incomprehensible mess. In-person doesn't generally allow such pauses in response time, though my inner circle has learned not to be offended by my silence. I feel pressured to respond before I'm comfortable and often fear that I've said the wrong thing or miscommunicated something important. ... but with my inner circle, even though I fear being misunderstood (or, worse, feeling inarticulate), I prefer in-person because it gives me an opportunity to communicate what words cannot. With them (and no one else), I prefer hugs, an arm around their shoulder, or resting my head on their shoulder. I don't need words, I need physical presence of someone who cares. That matters (to me) a whole lot more than words generally do.

The best method of communication involves: Face to face communication. It’s much easier to express the meaning behind the communication when people can be in each other’s presence and interact.Reciprocal. Communication is an exchange of information. It is best when it is two way and both sender and receiver have the opportunity to clarify what has been said until there is mutual understanding.Kind. Kindness is a way of showing respect. It is assuming the best in others and treating them that way.Honest. When you tell the truth, a person is in a better position to respond fully. Withholding information and/or not being truthful will cause a person to respond to the wrong communication.Straightforward. When you are indirect, people have to guess at what you really mean and some people are bad at guessing. They may either miss what you are “hinting” at or guess wrong.Communication is a bit of a miracle when you think about it. One person must get an idea that’s in his/her head into the head of the other person without any misinterpretation. We can use the 5 senses to accomplish this, part of which is our use of words and the way they are communicated. There are so many possibilities for miscommunication. Yet everyday, we are more likely to be successful than unsuccessful, especially when we use the 5 tips I outlines above.

My preferred method of communication is silent. Ninety three percent of Human communication is through body language whilst only seven is with actual words. You can tell so much about person just by their eye contact, facial expressions and involuntary giveaways (such as blinking when lying, scratching the chin in disbelief or an averted gaze).I work in an open kitchen so I get to study Human behavior all day long. You know when a girls really into a guy when she sits forward, plays with her hair and gazes longingly into his eyes. Time and time again I see the guy ignore the signs and get out his phone. I feed off these behavioral clues, rarely have I come across someone I can't read. But. Actual communication with words? I'm rubbish at that. Can't do it. One of my worst nightmares is being stuck in a room with someone I don't know. I go quiet, I stare at the wall. My heartbeat quickens. Panic sets in. Ugh. I am much better at communicating through text. I have spent fifteen years honing my skills at chatting to people in text based environments. I'm pretty good at inflection through emoticons. There's no need for an immediate response (even if it's just a few seconds to reply). I can use elaborate expressions to imply intellect :) Overall, think of me as the strong silent type.

Action. They say actions speak louder than words, and it's one of the most accurate clichés. A kind word can make someone's day, a kind action can make someone's week. They say three little words are meaningful, but cooking someone's favourite meal, or giving them a hug on a bad day, or even just the way you look at them will say ‘I love you’ more clearly, more beautifully, and more honestly than any words ever could. If a picture is worth a thousand, then an action is worth a million. Words may echo but actions reverberate through years and lifetimes. History is built upon the actions of people, and words without actions have proven futile. Words may define a nation but actions will create it. Think upon the most powerful things people have ever told you, and the most powerful things people have ever done for you, or to you. Words have limits, they can be confused, mispoken, misinterpreted. They elude many, and can be hard to remember. They're fickle, and don't stick. They can be twisted, or used to lie. The most important things can always be said without them, so they serve a logistical purpose at most. Actions are honest, straightforward, and pure.

These days, there are so many forms of communication, with new ones taking hold on society all the time, it’s definitely a difficult question to answer. But as far as what I prefer, as a 20-something year old that doesn’t have her nose in her phone all day, these are my preferred methods and why: Email: Truly the modern day letter. It can be professional or casual, and nowadays you can get notifications for them so they are read and answered speedily. Texting: Only for short communication like, “I’m here” or “when do you want to get together?” Longer conversations can easily get misconstrued through text, as sarcasm and teasing can often be misinterpreted. Meeting in person: Definitely my favorite. Gesture, personality, and facial expressions make a big difference in a relationship with a person. Snapchat: I do love Snapchat for speaking with long distance loved ones. Much like a text, but we can see each others faces and hear our voices. And they aren’t saved to your phone so only you and the other person knows what was sent between each other. Instagram: Kind of ideal for those friends you never see but you like to keep tabs on each other. Of course it’s useful for other things, but as far as interpersonal communication goes, it’s the least representative of each other’s emotions and well-being.

My preferred method of communication is face to face talk usually not involving a third person.  I prefer this because sometimes word are unable to convey the meaning. At that time its easy to guess what person is trying to say by watching its body language. Sometimes eyes say a lot. I find texting boring because it doesn't involve giggling,grinning etc.

Via text, Skype messaging, or similar mediums. I hate talking to people out loud. I'm expected to use proper (or at least somewhat proper) grammar, respond in real time with no space to think about what I’m going to say, and I can't go back and correct what I said. Also, for some reason I have trouble controlling the volume and tone of my voice, so that gets awkward. Digital communication also opens up the opportunity to use shorthand and slang that doesn't work in real life. Something exciting happened? ASJFJKHDKFKDJUDIEBJDKDKFJ Something funny happened? Lolol! (It's so hard to laugh in a way that isn't embarrassing). Also, there's no chance of me being able to hear the person I’m talking to because of a noisy environment, or because I zoned out, or because they tried to talk to me while I had headphones in. It's much easier to read and listen to music than it is to speak and listen to music.

You can use this pointers wherever you want. Be it while shopping at vegetables market or while buying a new car. I'm sure every point mentioned above will add bonus points to your communication. One to my right side and others to my left. We were at the signal for merely 30 seconds. Out of these 30 seconds the two rickshaw driver shared a lot of information between them without uttering a word. Let's see how. Once they stopped, first autorikshaw driver saw other autorikshaw beside his. Now to initiate the conversation first driver used proper communication channel as mentioned in first point I.e he honked two times that got other drivers attention including mine. USE OF PROPER COMMUNICATION CHANNEL. - DONENow, as we were on signal stop for few seconds both knows how much time they had to talk and share thoughts. It leads them to communicate in short i.e. first one raises his hands till forehead to mark a sign of first conversation intilisation in very short time. Now the real communication begins First driver indicates to other a left sided pointed hand gesture i.e. to tell him that his going to ride left side area from the next circle. First driver then pointed his hands to the mobile device held on the panel of his autorikshaw handle. Upon receiving O indication from second driver the first driver acknowledged and showed him V gesture mark with his hands. Thus communication happened in a clear, short and complete manner . I hope you got my points.

There is only one strategy. Talk. Evaluate their response. Does it match what you expected? Yes. Communicating effectively. Keep going. No. Not communicating effectively. Fix it. To fix it as efficiently as possible, do not repeat or rephrase. Instead, interrupt the flow of conversation with an apology. Share with them what you expected to see in the way of response. Let them know that it's fine that you didn't get that response. Let them know that however, because you did get a different response, that you want to make sure that you're not missing something. Then ask them to complete the picture for you by asking them, why did they respond that way? In most cases you will find that the words you were using meant something different. Asking this question is like asking which medical specialty is best. If you have cancer, an oncologist is best; if you have a sick child, a pediatrician is best. Each form of communication has its own strengths and weaknesses. Face-to-face is communication is the most emotional and personal. Written communication is best for conveying facts and science. This is expressed well in culture. Tribal cultures where the spoken word is dominant, tend to have close social and personal relationships. It wasn’t until the written word arose that science and formal education began — because research and factual information could be stored and could be extended based on previous learning. So… there is no “best” form of communication. The answer depends on how you wish to interact.

I don’t know what the “ones” are, so I’ll just give you my best viewpoint on your question that I can. Acting. Flicks of the eye, curls of the lips, even depths and lengths of breathing all tell you things about what characters think, feel, and are about to do, and they are all based on those of actual human beings. Every move we make, so long as it is not involuntary, gives us insight into what a person is thinking and feeling inside, and that can lead to not only understanding a person, but predicting their behavior. Perfect examples of this are the performances of actors that run contradictory to their own nature: Neither Jake Gyllenhall nor Heath Ledger were homosexual, however their performances in Brokeback Mountain were stellar and believable. Ian McKellen has both played a Nazi in Apt Pupil and a Holocaust survivor in X-Men. When you watch the way they move, talk, speak, and behave, you gain insight into their characters. Thus, everything that we do gives away information that is a form of communication to those wise enough to understand the language.
